sense.name: physically link or join two or more people, things, or parts
sense.examples: Can you connect the two loudspeakers? We connected the computers through their serial ports. A flagstone walk connected the main house with the tool shed. The two streets connect to become a highway. Let's connect by our arms and form a circle! Have they connected your cable yet? The telephone company finally put in lines to connect the towns in this area. Connect the TV so we can watch the football game tonight. Operator, could you connect me to the Raffles in Singapore?

sense.name: make a logical, psychological or emotional association
sense.examples: I cannot connect these two pieces of evidence in my mind. She always connected that house with family celebrations. Police are connecting the break-in with other recent thefts in the area. She's an actress I connect with the theater rather than films.

sense.name: establish a relationship or rapport
sense.examples: I really connected with the other kids my age who were going through similar experiences. The President of this university connects well with the faculty. Class of '59 connects with freshman. Did you finally connect with your long-lost cousin?

sense.name: establish communication
sense.examples: Operator, could you connect me to the Raffles in Singapore?

sense.name: strike, punch, or hit solidly
sense.commentary: Note: not used in a metaphorical sense - is physical
sense.examples: The brick connected on her head, knocking her out. The punch connected, and he sank to the ground. The batter connected for a home run.

sense.name: continue transport
sense.examples: The local train connects with the express twice a day. Those wishing to connect with the overseas flight please see the attendant at the gate.
